The truth and potential solution to the gender debate:

The gender debate is pretty pointless because itâ€™s really just about vocabulary. "Gender", first used in the 1400s, originally referred to grammatical categories, like in languages where nouns are male, female, or neuter (e.g., in Russian, tables are male, cars are female, windows are neuter). It wasnâ€™t until the 1950s that "gender" started being used for humans, but it was never meant to describe biological sex. It referred to roles, behaviors, and identities, separate from biology. This isn't a new concept though, as even some ancient cultures had more than 2 genders, each with their own gender roles. Over time, people started confusing gender and sex, thinking theyâ€™re the same thing, but theyâ€™re not.

The confusion comes from namespace collision: using terms like "male" and "female" for both, which causes people to argue that a trans woman is "really" a man. But thatâ€™s missing the pointâ€”gender is how a person feels, looks, and identifies, while sex is biological. So, saying a trans woman isnâ€™t "real" because of her biological sex mixes up the definitions of sex and gender. Both terms have existed separately from the start. Whether or not being transgender is a mental illness is irrelevant.

I propose that the namespaces are separated so that gender pronouns are separated from sex pronouns. Since the biological namespace used the words "male" and "female" first, it should get to keep the terms, and the gender namespace needs its own words. One way to do it is suffices.

As a physician and a scientist (M.D,PhD), I would like to make clear that 1) we do not employ the word â€œgenderâ€ in the natural sciences as this is a social concept. 2) Although you may have learned that XX is a woman and XY is a male, that is because biology like math is foundational, so many concepts are simplified in the primary and secondary educational settings. In the scientific community we have robust debates on terminology and arrive a consensus based on the current body of knowledge. The XX and XY concept of biological development is considered incorrect in scientific literature. In science, we first distinguish between people who are or are not capable of developing  primary (before puberty) and secondary (after puberty) sexual characteristics. This is because there are four genotypes that can give rise to a female with primary sexual characteristics (XX, XO, XXX, and XY (rare cases). Only two genotypes, however, give rise to both primary and secondary characteristics and fertility (XX, XXX). It is interesting to note that all fetuses will develop primary female characteristics unless the presence of one gene on the Y chromosome is present and functional. The scientific community first defined a female as anyone without a functional SRY gene, and male as any viable fetus with a functioning SRY. Whose genotypes may be (XY or XXY, OY is not viable). 
The point is that this is a complicated issue treated much differently in the natural sciences, so please refrain from invoking biology or science in anything related to the trans debate. These are purely social issues not scientific ones.
